definition: a word that joins words, phrases or sentences, for example ‘and’, ‘but’, ‘or’ or ‘because’
a combination of events, etc., that causes a particular result
the fact of stars, planets, etc. passing close together, as seen from the earth
together with somebody/something
a short sound, word or phrase spoken suddenly to express an emotion. Oh!, Look out! and Ow! are interjections.
slow, calm and relaxed
quiet, especially in a way that lacks excitement
to give a loud, high shout, because you are hurt, frightened, excited, etc.
to shout something in a loud, high voice because of fear, anger, etc.
to make a loud, high noise; to move fast, making this noise
if you drag somebody kicking and screaming to do something, they only do it with great protests because they don't really want to do it at all
to scream loudly and for a long time, especially in order to protest about something
a small, narrow river
a continuous flow of liquid or gas
a continuous flow of people or vehicles
a continuous supply of something; a large number of things that happen one after the other
a continuous flow of video or sound sent over the internet; a continuous flow of computer data or instructions
a group of students of the same age and level of ability in some schools
to be in operation or available
to experience something, especially something unpleasant or difficult, while you are trying to do something else
to meet somebody, or discover or experience something, especially somebody/something new, unusual or unexpected
a piece of jewellery that is cheap and has little artistic value
a decoration for a Christmas tree in the shape of a ball
to spend time and/or energy doing something
to annoy, worry or upset somebody; to cause somebody trouble or pain
to interrupt somebody; to talk to somebody when they do not want to talk to you
to think that somebody/something is important
used to say that you do not want to spend time and/or energy doing something
in a state of worry or stress because you are under too much pressure, have a problem, are trying to hurry, etc.
to not spend time/effort on something, because it is not important or you are not interested in it
causing difficulty or disagreement
having thorns
a verb such as be or become that connects a subject with the adjective or noun (called the complement) that describes it
an act of increasing or making something increase in size, amount or importance
the fact of doing or saying the same thing many times
a thing that has been done or said before
the process of repeating a mathematical or computing process or set of instructions again and again, each time applying it to the result of the previous stage
a new version of a piece of computer software
a subject that you talk, write or learn about
not appropriate or relevant to the situation
appropriate or relevant to the situation
a sticky substance that is a mixture of two proteins and is left when starch is removed from flour, especially wheat flour
long and thin, like the legs of a spider
a man who has never been married
a person who has a Bachelor’s degree (= a first university degree)
a small apartment suitable for a person living alone
a male cat
a male cat
a small worm that usually lives in water and that attaches itself to other creatures and drinks their blood. Leeches were used in the past by doctors to remove blood from sick people.
a person who depends on somebody else for money, or takes the profit from somebody else’s work
a large vehicle for carrying heavy loads by road
an open railway vehicle for carrying goods or animals
a vehicle that is open at the back, used for carrying goods, soldiers, animals, etc.
a vehicle for carrying things, that is pulled or pushed by hand
to refuse to deal with somebody; to refuse to accept or consider something
a seabird with long wings and usually white and grey or black feathers. There are several types of gull.
the act of delaying something that you should do, usually because you do not want to do it
a young cat
the young of several other animals, such as rabbits and beavers
to be very anxious, angry or upset about something
a person or thing, or the name of a person or thing, from which a place, an invention, a discovery, etc. gets its name
a newspaper or magazine that deals with a particular subject or profession
used in the title of some newspapers
a written record of the things you do, see, etc. every day

a type of large thin book with a paper cover that you can buy every week or month, containing articles, photographs, etc., often on a particular topic; a similar collection of articles, etc. that appears regularly online
a radio or television programme that is about a particular topic
the part of a gun that holds the bullets before they are fired
a room or building where weapons, explosives and bullets are stored
a magazine that is published every week, month, etc., especially one that is about an academic subject
a specialist who treats a particular type of illness or problem, or who uses a particular type of treatment
a person who is trained to treat somebody who has problems with their mental health by talking with them
a word such as the, some, my, etc. that comes before a noun to show how the noun is being used
the process of becoming smaller
a sudden and painful contracting of muscles, especially the muscles around a woman’s womb, that happens when she is giving birth to a child
a short form of a word
to spell a word wrongly
the act of adding something to something else in order to make it stronger or more successful
a drink or medicine made by leaving herbs, etc. in hot water
an act of slowly putting a drug or other substance into a person’s vein; the drug that is used in this way
containing a lot of fat; consisting of fat
rather fat
strong and thick
brave and determined
covered in a lot of grease or oil
cooked with too much oil or fat
producing too much natural oil
friendly in a way that does not seem sincere
used to refer to the difficult way to the top of a profession
a person that somebody is opposed to and competing with in an argument or a battle
a person who strongly opposes somebody/something
an enemy
frightening in a way that makes a person feel less confident
showing a desire to punish somebody who has harmed you
an indirect word or phrase that people often use to refer to something embarrassing or unpleasant, sometimes to make it seem more acceptable than it really is
a note or notes added to a book or text giving explanations or comments; the act of adding these notes
an idea suggested by a word in addition to its main meaning
a large, heavy bag that opens into two parts
yes; all right
used to attract somebody’s attention or to introduce a comment
used to check that somebody agrees with you or understands you
used to stop people arguing with you or criticizing you
a person who is captured and held prisoner by a person or group, and who may be injured or killed if people do not do what the person or group is asking
something that you have, or have promised to do, that could cause trouble or worry in the future
likely to last for a long time without breaking or getting weaker
continuing to exist or to have an effect for a long time
lasting for a long time
an act of shaking somebody’s hand with your own, used especially to say hello or goodbye or when you have made an agreement
the study of the meanings of words and phrases
the meaning of words, phrases or systems
(in the past) a song or tune played or sung at night by a man outside the window of the woman he loves
a gentle piece of music in several parts, usually for a small group of instruments
a person who travels to a holy place for religious reasons
a member of the group of English people (the Pilgrim Fathers) who sailed to America on the ship The Mayflower in 1620 and started a colony in Massachusetts
connected with music; containing music
with a natural skill or interest in music
pleasant to listen to, like music
a set of rooms, especially in a hotel
a set of matching pieces of furniture
a piece of music made up of three or more related parts, for example pieces from an opera
a set of related computer programs
